The right amount of spiciness to it, but isn't for the faint of heart, with a nice moist cornbread filled with little bits of real corn. The hurarche and carnitas were superb as well, but not the most memorable for me. My only criticism was that the carnitas itself was a little drier than expected. Besides that, all food options were great and are great to split as small dishes/tapas style with friends! 

DRINKS: So many drinks. I got a Chilcano this time, which wow. Delicious. The pisco, the citrus-y lime and hint of passion fruit with bitters note at the end. 

Enjoy the view, eat the small bites, and soak up that great California weather!
author: Albert H.

description: We were told by our AirBnB guest that this was a great rooftop with cheap happy hour margs. That's normally not my style, but my girlfriend can take down margs with the best of them. The view is terrific and the margs are actually really good. It's a perfect spot to have a nice view, have some nice drinks, and enjoy life.
author: Nick D.

description: Put our name down around 9pm on a Friday night, was told the wait would be around 45 min and they would text us when ready. 10-10:15 still no text. The woman proceeded to tell us it'll probably be another 30 before they can seat us but the kitchen closes at 10:45. Wtf thanks for wasting our time
author: Ashley R.

description:
Four of us stopped by El Techno on a Monday evening for dinner, and as expected, there was a bit of a wait. We added our group to the list and dropped into Lolinda for a drink. The overall wait time was maybe 20-30 minutes, which isn't so bad! 

We were seated and ordered from Edgar, who was friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. We ordered several things to share between the four of us: empanada de carne, empanada de zapallo, coctel de camaron, quesadilla de pibil, tostadas de alambre, and a pound of chicharrones. Everything was delicious, but I'd have to say my personal favorites were the coctel de camaron and chicharrones. 

Our water was refilled constantly, and the view can't be beat. The heat lamps provided some warmth for a cool night!
author: Sarah B.

description:
I've heard great things about El Techo but also have been warned about the long wait and crowdedness.  When I found out our friends were grabbing dinner here I  mentally prepared myself for the potentially very long wait. When we arrived at El Techo, our party checked in but we couldn't go up until we were called and until every person in our group was there. That's pretty typical but can get awfully annoying with a big group. Some of us were still in ubers. Others were waiting in Lolinda. We ended up checking in and then going back inside Lolinda's. About 5 minutes in they called us that our table was ready. My friends had to down their drinks since you're not allowed to take them outside.

We then took the elevator upstairs to the rooftop view. It was dark and we were inside the tent so there really wasn't much of a view. I would say just before sunset might be a prime time if you're hoping to catch a nice view of the city. 

Anyways, we ordered almost everything and two of everything from the menu. Overall my highlight was definitely the Paloma Margarita. If you're reading this you should totally GET IT! 

-Guac n chips. Must have.
-Coctel de Camaron. Great tangy shrimp appetizer.
-Esquite. They don't sell the Mexican corn on the cobb anymore but this is your next best substitute. I like to think of it as shaved Mexican corn in a little bowl. And it's easier to eat it this way. So yum.
-Chille Relleno. The first time I tried this dish, I loved it!! It's basically a stuffed pepper with cheese and tomato sauce. This one was unexpectedly S-P-I-C-Y hot. Beware! Still really good but I did not expect that much of a kick. 
-Carnitas. There were about 9 of us there that night and we were all hungry. We ordered two orders of the one & a half pound carnitas. It was the perfect amount. The carnitas were juicy and tender.  
-La Paloma. Grapefruit margarita. Best margarita ever. Now I will be on the hunt to see if I can ever find another grapefruit margarita as good as this one. 

Despite the wait and being crowded, thanks El Techo for a delicious and memorable first experience!
author: Grace J.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday. Love the crowd here, super lively. The view is great also!

We got here around 8PM, there was line to get in. So for dinner, there is NO RVSP, therefore make sure you go up to the front and ask to RVSP for a table. The line is just to go up for cocktail seating. We RVSP in the front and he said it will be an hour or so, so we stayed in line to just go up for cocktails. Then we got tricked into getting table instead of waiting for cocktail. And we were seated like where the kitchen was, not the business. Then I had a good conversation with the server and he moved us to another better table, but still kinda eh, so finally it was our turn for the RVSP table and got seated at the middle of area with heaters, great view. SO MUCH more worth it. 

We ordered: 
Guac and chips: Guac was SO good, sprinkled with cheese
Ceviche: Fresh, portion was kind of small though
Chicarron de carne: HIGHLY recommend. The pork shoulder was SO good , tender and sweet + salty. Comes with tortillas and beans.
Pina Colada: THE best I had so far, taste like a pineapple ice cream
Carne + Pollo Skewers: Kinda overcooked, but flavors and sauce were good

Overall great place to get together with friends, great view and food + drinks! Good find!
author: Natalie L.

description: They wouldn't let me upstairs to meet my date... after much ado and awkwardness I made it. But, the food, drinks, and mediocre view weren't worth it. There's a reasons other bars haven't survived at this location. You're not much different.
author: Doxie M.

description:
Great food, great view, but the staff ruins the whole experience.

They managers refused to serve our group margaritas because they were not familiar with Nebraska IDs. They were short and aggressive with us, even after we showed them multiple identifications. We were polite and completely sober and they literally told us to leave the restaurant.

Very disappointed.
author: Bryson S.

description:
Came here for drinks on a Sunday afternoon! The views of the city are priceless from their rooftop terrace. The atmosphere is very friendly, and service attentive. We did have to wait about 15 minutes to get in, which was no problem - but be warned, the building is not exactly in the nicest area - and they do make you wait outside.
My girlfriend and I did not order any food besides the chips and guac, however all of the dishes we did see looked awesome. The drinks are delicious, and if you order them by the pitcher they are a very good deal.
I will absolutely be returning next time we are in SF.
author: Kyle J.

description: HORRIBLE. No need for much more explanation. Location is cool, cool view but that is about it! Stood in line about 20-30 mins just to get to the terrace, once at the top, had 1 beer and was ignored the whole time! Not a place to chill and have beers and appetizers, serves could care less about you. CHURN IS HIGH HERE! lol so if ur looking for a cool spot to spend some time, pick somewhere else.
author: Roxann P.

description: Great place in the mission district for brunch! I got the huaraches for breakfast with a mimosa and it totally hit the spot! The wait can be a little long, so reservations beforehand is recommended.
author: Margaret P.

description: This place is awesome! Great rooftop patio dining, great food, and great service. We rented it for a private party and it was well worth it! I hear brunch on the weekend is phenomenal too.
author: Coleman T.

description:
3.5 stars. I came here for another lovely Sunday brunch with my good friend Nina Y. I didn't realize that El Techo was related to Lolinda, and I had visited Lolinda for dinner only a few weeks prior. I heard about the awesome rooftop bar, so I was excited to have both drinks and brunch here.

Nina and I arrived for our 11am reservation, only to find a long line out the door. Apparently everyone was waiting to get onto the elevator. We didn't make it to the rooftop until around 11:20am. So much for making a reservation. Once we were seated, we were spoiled with excellent service by our waiter. I wish I could remember his name.

We started off with cocktails, of course. I learned a very important lesson that day. NTS: Do NOT order a Bloody Mary with tequila (called a Bloody Maria) because it is not your cup of tea. Stick with vodka. Nevertheless, we enjoyed a beautiful view of the Mission District. If you are looking for a good brunch place in San Francisco and it's a sunny day, come here and sit facing the city.

We split a Benedictos and a half pound of Chicharrones de Carne. The Benedictos was alright. I was not a fan of the overpowering jalapeno cornbread, but it's always fun to try new styles of Benedicts. The Chicharrones de Carne is a MUST. Another friend recommended them to me, and those made the whole trip worthwhile. #MEAT

I would definitely come back here again, perhaps in the evening for a rooftop cocktail. I would also recommend any other brunch fanatics to add this to your list, specifically the Chicharrones!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Awesome roof top bar to spend the afternoon with friends. We arrived a bit before it opened, so there wasn't a long wait, but according to the gentleman downstairs it gets pretty crazy on weekends. We were promptly seated and started with a margarita pitcher, it was so good we ended up ordering two! Then at the suggestion of my friend I ordered a piña colada and it was amazing!!! Awesome service, excellent drinks and pleasant views, I will definitely be back!
author: Iris J.

description: Cool place to hang out and have a few drinks. Food menu has limited options, but food is delish. Food is more like a fusion of Mexican/South American
author: Leticia G.

description:
It was a cold evening when I checked in at the rooftop.

*I shivered.*

Counter Guy: Are you cold?
Me: Yes.
Counter Guy: Don't complain about being cold. I have to be here all day. 
Me: But you have a jacket.
Counter Guy: But you have Tequila.

Well played Counter Guy. Well played.  

The service from everyone at the rooftop was amazing. When you arrive, you first have to check in downstairs with a counter attendant lady before you can go upstaris. She is not the friendliest person. This is a popular restaurant, so there is quite a bit of a wait, especially if you have a large group. However, you can hop over next door to Lolinda's for drinks. There are two bars inside, one upstairs and one downstairs. If you don't finish your drinks by the time your table is ready, you can bring it up to the rooftop with you. There are heaters upstairs, so you won't freeze. The area is enclosed with clear covering, which blocks most of the wind, but part of the view as well. 

Upon arrival, we received chips and guac. The guac is really good. The waiter said the tostadas here was very popular, so that was what I ordered for dinner. It is a crispy tortilla with tomato braised beef brisket, pickled onion, cabbbage, queso fresco, and black beans. It tasted sweet. The pickled onion did not really taste pickled, but it was better that way. The pricing is not too bad too, it was only $8 for the tostadas, which came as a pair.

Overall, the atmosphere and food here is great, but I didn't think the view was that spectacular. But there's still something about eating on a rooftop that still makes it feel special.
author: Julia K.

description: Unbeatable view of the city, great atmosphere with both young and old professionals, good drinks and tasty street tacos! Must do this on your trip to San Fran.
author: Eric P.

description:
I came here for a late dinner, and it was so busy! I went here at 8 and had to wait nearly an hour for a table! And busyness is usually a good sign, but I wasn't blown away by anything, except the service! My server was super friendly and attentive. 

Foodwise, everything was ok, nothing exceptional. I tried the mango, empanadas de carne, pollo frito, and chicharrones. The mango basically tasted like fruit with Tajin seasoning. The meat (ground pork) in the empanadas wasn't really seasoned. I had super high hopes for the chicharrones based on all of the reviews, but the meat was a little too sweet for me. I also wished there were more vegetables for crunch. My favorite was the pollo frito. It's meat from the thigh, but there are no bones. It was seasoned really well, and I really liked the sauce that came with it. 

The ambience was just ok, as well. The dining area looked like it was filled with outdoor patio furniture. And the bar area was so packed. I'm not sure why they even put me in that area to wait for a table, since it was so crowded.
author: Rachel H.

description: Really great drinks! Awesome place for rooftop drinks on a nice day. Great views of the city. Food portions are really small so don't come hungry unless you are willing to spend.
author: Jessica E.

description:
Came here for my bachelorette party. The rooftop vibe was perfect! Drinks and food were delicious. The plantain chips were delicious as well as the margaritas! 
Must try with friends!
author: Nisha N.

description:
The food here is good (albeit, a bit pricey because there's plenty of cheap eats in the Mission!) and the rooftop is beautiful but the overall experience kinda kills it for me! he ambiance and lighting would be great if there just wasn't so many people! The seating feels pretty cramped and people kept brushing up against me. Seating is self serve, pretty much, and you have to keep an eye out for when there's space available. MEH. 

SO hectic and busy all the time. And I get why. There's no rooftops to go to in SF because it's so freakin' windy and cold all the time.
El Techo built a plastic wall on the rooftop and also has heaters everywhere - so you actually don't freeze to death - but that also means everyone tries to come here for the experience. A bit cray. Not really a place to relax, which is fine.

The wait outside can be long due to proximity of the space (small!) They can't let anyone in until someone comes out. So, that kind of blows. I think you can make reservations for dinner though but didn't find any section for it on the site, maybe you need to call? I highly recommend doing so if that's an option.

ANYHOW!
I've been wanting to come for ages and glad I finally did but don't think I'll return.

I ordered the chiccarones de carne that everyone raves about (half pound - for 2 people) and although it was good, I wouldn't come back just for it.
The meat was tender and easily shredded with a fork. So good! But wish it came with more salsa. Like. ALOT more of it. They only provided a little cup (the kind you use for ketchup)
author: Emily C.

description:
Such a positive experience with Jorge, who provided an exceptional experience, a warm and highly appreciated attitude, and most of all warm birthday vibes. 

Highly recommend El Techo for birthdays and parties.
author: Nicholas R.

description:
Great Margarita, they have a mice rooftop patio which I highly recommend. The view is gorgeous!

The wait wasn't too bad when we went there on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
1- RSVP for sure
2- was here for brunch, a group of 6, tottaly fit for the number 
3- food was excellent
4- coffee was great, drinks were yummy
5- rooftop location, sunny SF, what more can you ask for?
6- def. reasonably priced
author: Mary N.

description: Cool spot for brunch since you get to sit on the roof patio. I was just there recently for a friend's birthday and the service was awesome. We had a set menu and the food was pretty good. However, we ended up ordering a bunch of margaritas and shots so our bill racked up to nearly $100 a person! Overall, we paid for the ambience and the rooftop brunch vibe which is hard to beat :)
author: Jenn N.

description: tl;dr great drinks, ok food, poor service. Went to El Tech with a friend for Saturday lunch. Food was decent and tasty. However, I was disappointed that my dish promised pickled onions but came with raw onions instead - that's a pretty big flavor difference. Additionally, service was pretty slow and inattentive, and our waters were never refilled despite them sitting empty for a third of the time we were seated. That being said, the drinks were delicious, and I would definitely come back for the bar.
author: Christina T.

description:
The service was excellent, the food is amazing, although it was gloomy when we went, there's a clear tent w/ heaters so we enjoyed the romantic view without freezing!

Wait time on a Sunday night: NO WAIT (super shocking)
author: Precious C.

description: This is our favorite place to brunch when we are in the city. Get the empanadas and the carnitas plate, amaze balls!!!!
author: Brandon G.

description:
Finally tried El Techo for Brunch and fully enjoyed my experience here for so many reasons! For starters, the view is seriously breathtaking and the rooftop life is just so great especially when it's a little sunny outside! 

In terms of food, here are a few highlights (I also order vegetarian for everything, but bet it would be awesome with Meat): 
- Eggs Benedict - the Jalapeno cornbread is so moist and has such a great kick to it! 
-Techo Rancheros - I wish the fried egg was less over done, but the overall dish itself was super tasty and the hot sauce was great! 
-Scramble - just your regular scramble but so much flavor from the chipotle and roasted potatoes! 
-Guacamole and chips - I wish chips naturally came with your dish, but the guac had a great avocado and lime tastee!! 
-Bunuelos (Beignets) - Same consistency as a donut and that carmel sauce is so decadent! 

Top all this off with their really intentional servers and drinks - this is one of the best brunch spots in the city! Our server was super nice and always asked if we needed anything. In addition to this, the sangria packed a real good punch and was not too aggressive. I would come here again in a heart beat. Also, do not forget to make a reservation - you won't regret it!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
More like 3.75 stars! 

I've had El Techo bookmarked for such a long time. Rooftop dining and an affordable menu?! Yes, please! My boyfriend and I dined here on Valentine's Day. El Techo only takes reservations for their weekend brunch, unfortunately; but we only had to wait about 15 minutes and it was 7 pm! The restaurant's system texts you when your table is ready and you have 10 minutes to claim it. You take an elevator to the rooftop, where you are greeted by another hostess and taken to your table. As soon as the elevator doors opened, I was blown away by the view. The view was definitely the best part..

Our waitress lacked personality, and it took her forever to come back to take our order, though we made eye contact several times. The other waiters/waitresses/busboys who we came into contact with, however, were so friendly and personable. This place definitely has a fun atmosphere! So much so that it was so incredibly loud. We couldn't hear each other without using our outside voice lol. 

We ordered a pound of chicharrones ($22) and the choripan with a fried egg on top (+$2). The chicharrones comes with a bean purée, veggies, salsa, and fresh tortillas. Don't underestimate the size of a pound; it was more than enough for two. The choripan was just okay; I honestly wouldn't order this again. 

Overall, it was a nice experience. The view alone was worth it. I really want to try their brunch menu! Stay tuned. ;)
author: Liana B.

description:
El Techo is the perfect place to go on a sunny day. It provides fantastic views of the city and has a great bumping and hip ambiance. While personally not a huge fan of their food offerings (they have a pretty limited menu), I know most of my friends love the food. I think the drinks there are good though and appropriately priced for the venue and being in SF. My one hindrance would be the service -- can sometimes be tough to grab their attention and it seems slightly understaffed the three times I've been. Otherwise, great place.

Tip: try and beat the crowd by coming before 5pm - there's limited spacing on the roof.
author: Lucy G.

description:
First off hipsters, it's techo like te-cho (Spanish for roof and -cho like Margaret Cho & TCHO chocolate), not tech-o (because Earth to Matilda, not everything is about tech). Nothing makes me cringe like overhearing people simultaneously rave about and butcher "el tecko."

Now that I finally got that off my chest, this is about as good of a view you'll get in San Francisco with all the perks of outdoor drinking. For being such a beautiful city, there is literally an abysmal amount of rooftop bars. There are a couple of outdoor patio bars a couple of floors up and there are a few higher up indoor bars with great views, but El Techo is pretty much the only one that encompasses both.

Formerly Medjool, It took a little longer to open the rooftop after it became Lolinda, so the first time I came here the windows were super dirty and sort of took away from the view. I didn't return for nearly two years, but now it's one of my go to spots for having a chill day or night. You get a gorgeous, north-facing view of San Francisco's famous skyline, all while getting to enjoy delicious bar bites and just as delicious cocktails.

My second favorite part after the view-- the selection of Latin American liquors. Mezcal and pisco are my poisons of choice pretty much everywhere they're offered, and El Techo de Lolinda has some great cocktails with both. Palomas are great tequila drinks in general, but I often sub in mezcal to cut the citrus with some smokiness. El Escorpión is a sweeter, bright pink mezcal drink with prickly pear and ginger... also very good. For pisco, I either get the chilcano or a good ol' pisco sour. Recently I ordered the carioca with Brazilian cachaca, and that was also very refreshing. Drink prices run $9-13, which is pretty average now for anywhere even slightly upscale in the city, but I guarantee they are yummy. They also have pitchers so you can share with friends (or drink more to yourself, who knows).

Now let's talk food-- ceviche is a must. It's not quite as spectacular as the ceviche in the restaurant downstairs, but it's definitely a good filler with chips since they're pretty generous with shrimp. The carne skewers are also really delicious because they're grilled to juicy perfection and smothered in Lolinda's amazing chimichurri *droolz*. My friend got the chicharrones once, and it was a little overwhelming having a literal pound of pork shoulder to just dig in on. Instead, try the quesadilla de pibil for your porky fix because they're also bomb.

Tips: This place can get pretty busy on warm days (since those days are pretty rare), so brace yourself. On a chillier day, thankfully there are heat lamps everywhere and windows to help with the wind.
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description:
First of all just wanna start by saying how great the staff is here. I thought this was gonna be a hipster/techie spot and it kinda was but I still had a great time. The people who work there were all real genuine, friendly and down to earth folks. And that's refreshing in San Francisco now so shout out to them and whoever hired em.

View was nice. Food was over priced but tasted good and hey I don't mind paying extra for the experience. I had the fish tacos which were tasty, but not amazing 8/10. The chips and guacamole were the bomb though and paired great with tequila. 

I regret not staying longer and not trying more food there... I'll be coming back soon
author: Guerito L.

description:
Great rooftop restaurant and bar. All tables are located outside on the open-air rooftop. he food here is on point and it's a great Mexican spot. There's a great view of the mission and the food and service is great. 

They have happy hour from 4-6PM Monday to Friday. 
- $4 cerveza
- $5 bar bites
- $7 margaritas

Things I ordered: 
- 3 mix and match skewers - 2 carne and shrimp
- Guacamole with cotija, tortilla chips
- Ceviche de Camaron with shrimp, lime, radish, red onion, avocado, cilantro
- Quesadilla de Pibil with braised pork shoulder, oaxaca cheese, salsa
author: Jenn L.

description: Love this venue in the city. I love that this restaurant is on top of the roof and you can see beautiful views of San Francisco. I love their food especially their empanadas de carne y quesadilla de pork. Very relaxing place to enjoy the views while you eat or have a drink.
author: Angelica V.

description:
Awesome vibe and awesome food. Came here with a group of friends to catch-up and prefunk the night.  It was a chilly night but they had plenty of heaters around. El Techo is a rooftop dinner bar with a great view around the city. 

The food was surprisingly awesome.

We got the shrimp, beef, chicken skewers. They were bomb! Very flavorful and the chicken was juicy . 
The fried chicken was a nice appetizer it had a tangy sauce to keep it light. 
Pork quesadilla was solid as well and the margaritas really topped it off.
I'd say the only weak spot of our meal was the Empenada, something I felt like you can live without.

Overall sweet spot and definitely worth a visit. Would be a great date spot
author: Travis L.

description: Warning: if you accidentally leave before closing out and come back the next day to get your card, they'll tell you it's lost...sorry. So cool!!!
author: Olya S.

description: Saturday night, extremely busy. Came here for the first time, recommended by my friend who took me here. I must say the service was absolutely amazing. Jackie gave us amazing service with a seamless experience. We tried new drinks we've never tried before and loved it. She definitely made this visit a memorable one. Thank you Jackie !
author: Angelina D.

description:
If you've ever been to Lolinda (downstairs), you'd be an immediate fan of El Techo as the food is just as good and the view is better. It's tough to find a rooftop establishment in all of San Francisco, so for that and that alone, this place gets 5 stars. It's refreshing to be outside while dining and enjoying the many tequila/mescal cocktails that fill the menu. I'm actually surprised that I hadn't been there yet, as it's truly unique. 

I didn't eat while I was there, but gazed upon the many dishes that were flying out of the kitchen and it seemed like everyone was enjoying their food. Not sure why this place is classified as a "tapas bar" or Argentine, as it felt more Mexican to me, but what do I know...? I'll surely be back to sample the fare on a nice sunny day this spring.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
The view is amazing. 
It took a long time to get a pitcher of margarita, but then again you never know if it just was an overall busy day. 
Food looks amazing but I feel like this place is more for drinks
author: Maria K.

description: I've been here twice. The first time right after work on a Thursday night, there was no line and plenty of space. Love the outdoor heaters - definitely necessary. The drinks were standard. Cute rooftop spot. Definitely not really a view, since honestly it's not really a "rooftop" in the sense of height, but it's just an open outdoor space. The second time I came on a weekend and there was a half hour wait with someone at the door who let a bunch of people in randomly skipping the line. I wouldn't come back and wait in line, but I'd return on another day where there isn't a wait. There's no view or anything special to justify waits.
author: Marie D.

description: Great place to grab drinks and appetizers with friends!  My friends and I were visiting the city and wanted to grab drinks somewhere chill, nothing too crazy.  We decided on El Techo but there was a huge line/wait to get inside.  I thought it was so weird since its more of a restaurant kind of vibe? but I could see why once it was finally our turn and we were seated.  The seats are very limited on the roof top and its a very cozy setting.  I actually really liked the ambiance here and it was a great recommendation!  Since we were going wine tasting the next morning, we settled for pina coladas with chips n guac.  Now, if you know me then you know that I would probably never order pina coladas but I wanted to be on the same level as everyone else so why not.  To my surprise, the pina coladas were actually pretty strong, I got a slight buzz of them!  The guac was really good too, simple but you could taste the freshness.  Overall, I wouldn't mind coming back again, especially for dinner or maybe even brunch!
author: Regina O.

description: One of my friends is getting married and we decided to come here for a bridal brunch! This place is rooftop level and has beautiful views of San Francisco. All of us had an amazing time! The drinks were awesome, food delicious and customer service excellent. We ordered a lot and drank a lot too! Everything came out in a timely manner, the presentation of the food was good and taste was even better. This is definitely a very popular brunch spot so make reservations!
author: Daniella G.

description:
It's sunny in the City on a Sunday! Get your butt to El Techo, and quick.

I have been meaning to get to this rooftop spot for a few months but this El Nino weather has really been draggin' me down. So when Mr. Sun decided to make an appearance this last weekend and I had a visitor in town, we made a run for El Techo. The brunch menu has just enough to give you variety without being incredibly overwhelming. There's not many sweet treat options (I think just one French Toast option on this particular day) so just note that if you're a pancake fiend. 

For two people with no rezzys, we were still seated right away along the ledge (bar stools) with direct views of the skyline. We started off with some boozey brunch drinks (I recommend the Palomar I think it's called- tequila/grapefruit/lime/agave/soda) and my friend had a fresh squeezed pineapple mimosa. The ceviche was my least favorite thing we ordered, IMO it didn't taste very fresh and the portion was so tiny for $13 of chopped shrimp with small bits of barely existent avocado. I'd skip this next time.

But I was very pleased with my gallo pinto (the most tasty rice and beans I have ever had!) with fried eggs, fresh corn tortillas, and fried plantains. My friend had the eggs benny which come with a Spanish flare (I think like a chipotle hollandaise over jalapeno cornbread). Next time I want the side of cornbread instead of the ceviche. We tried the bloody Mary's too. they were just okay. Kind of weak tomato flavor but the pickled veggies were a nice touch.

Overall this place is good for brunch with view. On chillier days sit under the tent near the space heaters.
author: Miriam M.

description: Decent pitchers of stuff cool view and vibes. Couple hotties around but the tables were cramped. Gotta figure out the layout a bit
author: George N.

description: Everyone talk about the view and that the food is just okay but I actually thought it was pretty darn good!
author: Joana Z.

description:
I came here mid-day on Saturday this past weekend and found the wait to be worth it. It is a small place upstairs so once they're packed, they will let folks in once more leave. That makes it hard to tell how long the wait will be. If you're in a rush, or have places to be after at a certain time, I wouldn't recommend dining here.

The views from the top are breath taking and leave a pleasant vibe. I didn't have any meals here but we got a pitcher of margarita. They say it usually serves 5, but we had enough to serve a glass to six of us. The drinks were great! I'd definitely come back again.
author: Krishneel K.

description: The scenery at this restaurant has to be one of my favorites. A very young, vibrant, and chill vibe at the rooftop in SF. The food was decent, I've honestly had better but definitely not bad. The empanada de maiz and platano maduro were my favorites. However, I wish the menu had more options with bigger portions. I also wish our waitress came to our table more frequently, I feel like we waited on her quite a bit, although the service definitely was not horrible. I would definitely come again next time I'm in SF.
author: Melanie A.

description:
Food is alright. Not the best mexican food but not bad either.

Bit overpriced considering the mango appetizer was $8 for literally cut up mango & jicama sticks with chili powder sprinkled on top. Mango was hard too and my entree came with crushed eggshells in the dish.

The vibe and the rooftop makes up for it though. 

Overall, a good spot for a brunch on a sunny day
author: Ji K.

description:
Decided to finally check out El Techo after months of friends telling me it's crackin. I came here with a friend after work right when they opened and even though it was drizzling and freezing, their rooftop was nice and cozy! 

They have happy hour from 4-6 M-F I believe and the food is so worth it! Their guacamole is bomb and so is their pollo frito. We also had a pitcher of sangria and their chicharrones but personally it wasn't to die for. The meat was a bit too sweet for my liking but everything else was yummy. We also got the ceviche which I could do without next time. 

Overall, our server was awesome. Actually service is general was great. Everyone was super friendly and they let us sit at a 4 person table even when we were only a party of two. I will definitely be back!
author: Shelly W.

description:
Order the chicharrones (1lb = $26). It's enough to stuff 3 people... the meat was so tender and what's even better were the tortillas. Unbelievably fluffy, soft, and warm served with salsa and beans. Service was slow AF on a Friday night though. We had to flag down our waitress several times though I'm sure she was busy. 

Skip the drinks - too weak and watered down to justify the price. The view here is also great but prepared to wait especially if you're only coming to enjoy the rooftop bar. 

It's a good view of the SF skyline but it gets pretty cramped up there that you don't really get to enjoy it unless you're sitting right up against the window.
author: Cindy W.

description: WORST PLACE EVERRRRRRR!!! If you're pregnant, don't come! They'll make you wait outside in the cold for almost 2 hours to have dinner - telling you it's only a 45 minute wait. And every time you ask, they tell you, you're next. We never even got a chance to go in because hours later, THEY STILL DIDN'T HAVE A TABLE AVAILABLE! If I could give this place no stars, I would.
author: Angie S.

description:
Can't believe I don't have a review for this place! I celebrated my 23rd birthday here a couple years ago. Time flies! My biggest Yelp friend Mark A. recommended this place for my birthday dinner and it turned out perfect! 

I made reservations for ten and almost twenty people showed up. It was beyond hectic with a lot of my friends stuck downstairs by the elevator and the staff was doing their best to accommodate everyone. They did a fantastic job handling everything! The structure is kind of bizarre though considering its a restaurant/bar. It kind of has a club set up where people have to lineup downstairs and wait until people leave before they can take the elevator upstairs to the roof. 

I can't remember if I had it on a Friday or a Saturday but it was absolutely packed. Definitely try to come here early or make reservations for a table. The roof has a super trendy ambiance. Its loud, dark, and perfect for a birthday party. It was seriously the best birthday I had in my entire life. Food was great, ordered a ton of pitchers. Was never cold under the heat lamps except for when I had to go to the bathroom it was freezing around the corner. I would give it five stars but our tab was through the roof! I have no idea how that happened but there was definitely not that much food and drinks for how much the bill was. Thank god I was the birthday girl.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
If you want tapas, better come before 11 because kitchen closes at 11.

They have heaters but still a little cold. 

Also, not a lot of cocktail selection. But they have a lot of spirits.
author: Sarah L.

description: Waitress Monica tracked me down to tell me to pay her $2 more on the tip to reach 15%. Very rude and unacceptable behavior. Great food though.
author: Bailey H.

description:
This posh rooftop bar is an exciting, versatile place to meet. In theory, its awesome view of the neighborhood, tasty drinks, and lively vibe make it the perfect spot for a date, drinks with friends, or anything inbetween.

Add the population of a small country to that perfect idea of a spot and you have El Techo. Because it's such an incredibly trendy destination, lines for a table are off the charts. While the drinks themselves are great, I found myself waiting for an eternity to finally get something, and was getting elbowed by 100 different frantic people in the process.

I definitely want to come back and enjoy this place, but learn from my mistake that this will not be a breeze if you go at peak hours. Perhaps you should save this one for the very beginning or end of your Mission itinerary. I know I will!
author: Stephen D.

description: The chicharrones are amazing. Palomas are perfect! Service is fast and efficient. Their guac is pretty basic--could use some improvement.
author: Ana I.

description: I've been here a few times now and really enjoy the food. The quesadilla de pibil and the chicharrones de carne are always very delicious. On my most recent visit, I tried the pollo frito for the first time and I was very impressed. It was quite delicious. The service here is usually good, but I have had some experience with some staff who were kind of rude or inattentive. Other than that, this place is great and I will continue to come back here!
author: Balben D.

description:
I'm giving El Techo 3 stars instead of 4 just because it was very difficult to get in. I met some friends for post-Happy Hour drinks on a Friday evening (about 6:30/7pm) and there was a line of about 20-30 people. Luckily my friends were already inside, but I still waited several minutes for the host to call me up.

Once there, the servers were difficult to get ahold of (I chalk this up to being so busy, not bad service). The drinks came pretty quickly and were very good. And the views from the rooftop patio were awesome!
author: Miranda D.

description:
The only reason I know about this restaurant was because I went to a friend's birthday party yesterday and I didn't know what to expect, but I'm glad I got to experience everything! Our party of 10 was able to get a table closest near the view of the city, but the only thing was that we didn't have a heating lamp nearby, so most of us were pretty cold. I have to say though, never have I ate out on a rooftop before, so my first experience was amazing! The view of the city was SO beautiful, especially because the sun was setting and you were able to see the city lights, as well as the bay bridge.

The menu is very short and simple, which made it easy to order what we wanted to order. For my order, I ended up getting the quesadilla de pibil and the pamola drink (our whole table got two pitchers worth of it). I was also able to taste a bit of the chocolate tres leches cake and the flan.

THE QUESADILLA WAS AMAZING. The tortilla was thin,yet crispy. It reminded me of a pupusa  because of how it was made, but the braised pork was juicy and tender. The salsa that came along with my quesadilla had a citrus taste to it which actually went so well with it. Alongside the chocolate tres leches cake, I wished it had a bit more milk in it because it tasted like a chocolate cake with milk and coconut, but in the back of your throat, you taste a bit of sweetness from the condensed milk (but still pretty good!). Also, the flan was SUPER creamy. The custard itself was so light and airy, definitely felt like a cloud in my mouth. Lastly, the Pamola drink was pretty good! I don't think that much since I'm not much of the drinker, but the tequila wasn't overpowering and you were able to taste a bit of the grapefruit in the drink.

My dining experience was pretty great, but the only downside was that it took a while for servers to take our order since we were on the very opposite side of everything, there was really no space for us to move around a bit, and every single table had a heating lamp near them besides us. So, besides a few cons, I would definitely come here and explore their menu more.
author: Trisha L.

description: Food was delicious but the menu is limited. Service is also mediocre as the place is crazy busy. And not all seating has a view. Seats are also very uncomfortable. Just did not meet my expectations.
author: Vic G.

description: Came here a few weekends ago as my bride and I met a friend here on a Sunday afternoon.  Coming out of the elevator we felt like we walked into a beer commercial. Great views, great vibe. Our waiter was very friendly and attentive.  The food was excellent and enjoyed the beer selection.  The only downside was the price of a pitcher of margaritas seemed excessive.  I will be back.
author: Derald C.

description: Disclaimer, yelp says there are no reservation BUT thats not true. Reservations are available so please call them a day before. Anywho, I did not have a reservation, we came to this spot on day 3 of our vacation from Texas. I had booked this spot on my list when searching Yelp for a solid brunch spot. This place was top notch. We arrived 45 minutes before opening and got first spot in line. This area is very friendly as the marijuana dispensary next door houses a very nice door guy who will help you understand the FCFS protocol when you arrive w no reservations. When you arrive FCFS, when the hostess comes out, immediately put your name on the list. The service here was very friendly and accommodating. You want to get here first because of the rooftop bar spots. I recommend requesting these type of seats as they oversee a beautiful range of San Francisco. My gf and I definitely went hard here with two pitchers of their strong margaritas. Their food was fresh as well. This would be an amazing spot for a group but also a nice brunch spot for a couple looking to get loose. If I lived in San Francisco this would def be a go to spot for brunch every couple of Saturdays.
author: Steven L.

description: Happy hour is awesome on a nice day.  Standing room for drinks and small bites but everyone is happy and drinks and snacks are good deals.
author: V N.

description:
I can see myself frequenting this place for their drinks and enjoying the outdoor ambiance with a gorgeous view of the SF financial district skyline. This is somewhere I would have never expected to be in San Francisco, but it is a true hidden gem!

When you first get here, you'll probably see a line outside Lolinda to get to the rooftop. Note that if you want dinner here, tell the person at the front so they can put you on the waitlist and you can go to other bars around the area before they notify that your table is ready through a text message. So my friend and I didn't have to wait long at all and immediately got to ride the elevator up within 10 minutes or so waiting in line.

We ordered their margarita and chilcano, with a side of their chips and guacamole. We also decided to try their carne empanadas and their chicharron later on in the evening. The chicharron was by far my favorite dish! It comes with tortillas, black beans, salsa, vegetables, and pork shoulder (you choose the portion size!) I loved the glaze and flavoring of the pork shoulder! The portions look small, but they got me pretty full by the end of the meal (my friend's a big guy, and he was full even with leftovers). All in all, it was a great experience! We were about to leave, but I wanted to stick around and enjoy the atmosphere of lights hanging above our heads, heat lamps, and the beautiful night view of the city.. so we ended up snagging a free-for-all table and enjoyed another round of drinks. Their pina colada is on point! 

Definitely one of my favorite spots in the city by far for catching up or date night ;) It can get a little loud up there, but worth it? YES.
author: Kathleen S.

description: I enjoyed my visit to El Techo for the most part, lovely view. My issue is when the check came I paid with split tender & went about my day. The next day I noticed my card was incorrectly charged. I left a voicemail for the manager about the issue, received a confirmation call that he would look into & never heard from him again. I've tried to contact him numerous times since, with no luck. Safe to say I'm not going back.
author: Elvie D.

description:
The elevator up was exciting. 
Had a couple of cocktails delicious 
We had the quesadilla and every skewer they offer. I would recommend the beef and shrimp skewers 
you come for the view and the aesthetic, but you STAY for the salsa
author: Riki K.

description:
= Drinks are good, but over priced. Opt for the pitchers if you can - they are a better deal.
= Asked for spiciest salsa they have - GAVE ME CHOLULA. 
= Portions are small
= Great decor/atmosphere
author: Jean C.

description:
Place: Great ambience and views of SF at night. 

Wait time: We were a group of 7 and had to wait 90 mins to get seated. 

Service: The food got out quicker than expected. Service was slow after we got done though (bringing us the cheque).

Food: It was alright (we tried the fried chicken, empanadas de carne, choripan and quesedilla), but definitely not worth the 90 minute wait.

Overall experience: The only reason I wasn't unhappy at the end of it was because we were taking a friend out to dinner who was visiting SF and catching up in the wait lines served as a big distraction.
author: Neysa F.

description: Worst experience at a Mexican restaurant. It began with service, server was just slammed with at least taking 7 different parties including a 8 top and a 6 top. That's not all all of their food seems it was from at least more than one day, how can I say that well Guacamole had much lime what does that tell me that it's old and for it to maintain they put lime( yes I know the trick I'm Mexican) then Watermelon water was as well with so much lime that was ok I can say. Finally I order the carnitas and my wife the chilaquiles. Chilaquiles were great but carnitas !!! Man they were just old and chewy and all hard. Beans tasted so bad I really barely ate half of it, owner or who ever is in charge should definitely change recipe. For 63 dollars i could have gone to a taco shop and had better food
author: Leo Q.

description: What a fun brunch spot for sunny days in SF. Reservations are a must and even with them, you'll likely be waiting in line outside on the street while patiently waiting for the elevator. This rooftop gem hosts amazing views and a super fun staff which always has us desiring an extra shot of tequila and the notion that we want to loiter for just a bit longer once our Mexican plates are clean. Great spot for friends to begin a Sunday-Funday!!
author: Maggie F.

description: I was visiting San Francisco a couple weeks ago for my friends birthday. We had heard about a cool rooftop bar and decided to try it out. Let me just say that place was spot on! It was a weeknight and it was really busy. The wait took a little longer than we thought but once we got in we were helped right away. Our server Shelby recommended the pollo frito and the corn empanadas. They were so good and on happy hour! I'll DEF be back when I'm back in the city!
author: Kory L.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the city for HH. Happy hour runs from 4-6pm Monday thru Friday!! Yes lets just let that Friday soak in for a bit, I couldn't believe it myself that a decent place has HH on a Friday either!! The entrance to El Techo is located right next door to Lolinda, you check in with the host downstairs, take the elevator upstairs, and another host upstairs seats you. 

On my most recent visit to El Techo, my friends and I were craving sangria so I figured this would be the perfect place. A carafe is $18 at HH, so we got three of them... There were four of us and we left feeling the perfect buzz. There are some bites during HH as well - Chips and Guacamole, Empanadas, and Chicken Fritters all for about $5, which is so much cheaper than their regular menu price. 

There is a beautiful view of the city (especially because there are zoning laws that don't allow buildings higher than 40 feet in some neighborhoods) so we got a great view of the downtown skyline from where we were. There are large glass windows to shield you from that SF wind and heat lamps to keep you nice and cozy. We went on a rainy day, which was perfect since it was empty, and they have a whole set up to keep everyone nice and dry. Highly recommend for HH!
author: Elaine N.

description:
No wonder this place has amazing ratings!
My roommate and I came here for drinks and dinner on a Thursday night. This place was surprisingly/not surprisingly crowded. I got a little confused because El Techo's sister restaurant, Lolinda, is downstairs and we were confused on where to check-in. There's also a random velvet rope with a line of people aggressively standing behind it -- as if it's the newest nightclub.
We checked in with the host downstairs where he told us it would be about a 30-45 minute wait. Less than 5 minutes later, we got a text saying that our table was ready! Super quick. After a short elevator ride, we were greeted by friendly staff and seated at an amazing table. The views are incredible -- you can see the SF skyline without being all the way in Marin County. It was cold and windy that night, but the rooftop is well-insulated and has plenty of heaters. Neither of us were cold. 
The food and service here is great! We ordered the Guacamole, Chicharrones de Carne, and the Shrimp Ceviche (?). All of it was great, but I highly recommend the Chicharrones! They are not the traditional, crunchy ones that you get from a Mexican market. It's like pulled-pork, Mexican style. I loved it!
I ordered a Cucumber Margarita here, which was also great. I think it was a little too sweet for my taste, but it was super refreshing!
5 stars all around for El Techo. I can't wait to come back!
author: Zoe Y.

description:
If only more restaurants could follow what "El Techo de Lolinda" does, then we'd all be taking breathtaking photos. And the reason I say this is because the view of San Francisco from this place already had me sold. I'm a sucker for scenery and in this day in age where just above everyone is posting pictures on their Instagram, Facebook, and Yelp, we've all become talented photographers over the past few years. Well, I'm more going to focus on the food, service, and experience that I encountered here.

Located in the heart of the Mission District on 21st and Mission St's, "El Techo de Lolinda" is one of the trendiest Tapa rooftop bars in the city by the bay. I came here on a foggy (but rather cold) Sunday evening with my fiancée, our friend, and his wife. Since I have never been to this place before, I had no idea what to expect. After we parked in the nearby parking garage, we walked to the front of the building where the hostess said there would be a little bit of a wait. Luckily it was only about 5 minutes and were proceeded to go inside.

This is where we took an elevator three flights up to the roof! Keep in mind for those that want a warm indoor dining experience; you will be sitting outdoors on a roof! However, the entire roof is shielded and protected by plexiglass as well as many heating lamps to keep you snug during those extremely chilly San Franciscan days (and nights). There are many tables situated throughout the rooftop as well as a separate bar area, a main kitchen area, and restrooms that are towards the rear of the rooftop. The main building itself looks as if there are several apartments that are below this place. I sure hope these walls are sound-proof because up top it gets awfully noisy!

Once all four of us are seated, we do notice how cramped everything is. I literally bumped into the person behind me when I moved my chair so it can get a bit claustrophobic. But overall, none of us were cold by any means even though the air temperature felt as if it was about 54°. Our server hands us menus while we all decide on what to order. Since this is a "Tapa-styled" place, they offer a nice variety of smaller plates. And the menu is very South American; much like what you'd expect if you were dining in Argentina or Chile.

My fiancée and I decided on splitting an order of their "1lb. "Chicharrones de Carne" (for $22.00). This is essentially roasted and fried pork-shoulder belly chunks complete with their own house made tortillas, lime, salsa, and Escabeche (which is a type of marinade mixed in with the pork). We also decide on ordering a side of "Guacamole" (for $7.00) which included tortilla chips and Cotija cheese set over black refried beans. And since this was our last meal before heading back home (to Sacramento), we decided to skip the alcoholic beverages and settle with good old Mexican Coca-Cola. However, they do offer a very respectable cocktail bar which also includes an excellent amount of beer, wine, and sangria.

As busy as it was (every table was filled), our server was always upbeat and in a positive mood. Our chips and guacamole came out in less than 5 minutes while our Chicharrones de Carne arrived just 10 minutes after that. I've gotta say, the portions here are huge! The overall flavor was very tasty but a little bit on the sweet side. The meat itself was very tender, juicy, and had good consistency to it. Luckily we were able to spice it up with some green Habanero sauce. I definitely think this was more than enough food to feed 3 or even 4 people but I was quite satisfied with how this came out. 

I do have to say, if it wasn't for the rooftop bar as well as how positive our server was, I'd only give this place 3-stars. But the experience all in itself is what makes "El Techo de Lolinda" unique in comparison to other places I've dined at. If you're only going for small bites or even a light brunch during Happy Hour, then this view is worth checking out. Definitely an experience that everyone should see sometime they're in San Francisco!
author: Donovan H.

description: I don't really get the hype? Like, it's a rooftop bar, and you've got a nice view, granted, but it's as windy and cold as Mount Rainier, the drinks aren't *that* great, and the bar bites are so small as to be fit for ants, not people. Plus, the line is just about forever long, so the general enthusiasm for this place is a little bewildering to me.
author: John L.

description:
Got to El Techo and waited about 30 minutes for a table which wasn't so bad for a Saturday night and I didn't mind the wait. When we finally made it up they don't really have many food options if you're looking for a bigger plate. It took a good amount of time for the waitress to finally get to our table and we decided to get the meat empanadas, cocktail de camaron, mango plate, and La Paloma to drink. They were all really good but I do wish they offered a bigger plate for those. La Paloma was not too sweet which to me is perfect!! After about 30 minutes we got to order the chocolate tres leeches which I was really excited about but it did taste a little dry. The hard part was getting a waiter so we could pay and head out. El Techo has a lovely view, it's pretty loud, does have some heaters so you're not freezing, has small tables which can get a bit uncomfortable, but has some pretty tasty stuff. 

Will go back to check out what the morning scene is like!
author: Claudia A.

description: Haven't been to this place since it changed hands. Rooftop over looking the city is always a treat even on cold, rainy, and windy days. Typical Mexican fare with solid margaritas.
author: Linda H.

description: Very nice place with a cool rooftop bar that has nice tables you can have dinner on.  The Mexican food is done very well.  The service is good and it is a popular place.
author: Thomas P. L.

description: For the price, the taste of the food was somewhat lacking. The drinks however are great and I would highly recommend to go for the margaritas with friends, sitting on the rooftop!
author: Tanny M.

description:
Came by El Techo on a Friday afternoon to take advantage of the happy hour with a friend. The covered seating was very welcome since it was a cold, rainy day -- there are also outdoor heaters, which keep you nice and toasty warm. 

When you get there, the people sitting out front will direct you to take the elevator up. Once on the rooftop, you'll be greeted again and then seated. The server checks your ID when he takes your order. Everyone was super friendly. 

My friend and I had their HH margaritas ($7!) and oh boy, such strong drinks! But good! We also ordered the guacamole and chips ($5 during HH) and the ceviche off their regular menu. The guac was delicious -- nice and creamy, and green so we could tell it was freshly made. The ceviche was YUMMY, nice and citrus-y and had a really nice kick to it. If you can't handle spicy food, you may want to pass on this. 

Our server was super attentive the whole time we were there, coming by every now and then to see if we'd like to order more drinks or food (without being annoying). 

If you're in the Mission and looking for a good HH place, I'd recommend El Techo! I'd imagine the rooftop would be much more appealing on a warm, sunny day too!
author: Doris K.

description:
Obviously a ridiculous scene being one of the very few rooftop restaurants or bars in San Francisco.

The carnitas is absolutely fantastic. Ordering 1 pound of carnitas is a great way to go and a great value.

It's also nice to be able to get pitchers of some of the cocktails (paloma, margarita) although the paloma was sadly not as grapefruit-y as we wanted.

Surprisingly good value overall and a fun place to hang out, have a bite to eat, and some delicious drinks on a sunny afternoon!
author: Amy D.

description: Great brunch menu. I had the chorizo scramble and friend Huarache plate which looked amazing. They have "ague Fresca" mimosa. I was told it was watermelon but turned out robbery cantaloupe.  It was OK. Others enjoying traditional mimosas looked like they had too much OJ (hence the 4 stars). Service was excellent and attentive.
author: Monica O.

description:
You can tell the staff really enjoys working here. Combine that with unique Latin dishes, strong drinks, and a memorable skyline view, and you've got an experience that never gets old. If it weren't so dang hard to get a seat around sunset when the view is at its best, I would give five stars.

Tip: start lining up before they open their doors for dinner.
author: Jason J.

description:
*** In Short ***

Rooftop restaurant with a great view, but pretty average brunch fare.

*** In Depth ***

So, the highlights: the view from the rooftop (which is pretty well shaded), is surprisingly nice and expansive for a building less than five stories high; and, they take reservations for brunch, which is exceedingly rare to find here.

That's pretty much it, because the food, while in no way bad, also didn't stand out enough to warrant a return visit, when there are so many other brunch options in the city. The fluffy and crisp bunuelos were easily the best part of the meal; followed by the huarache, of which the brisket itself was pretty flavorful; and then lastly, the somewhat plain and uninspired benedictos, which came with two poached eggs, one overcooked to the point of being hardboiled (in their defense, they did offer to replace it).

2.5 stars for now, since it's pretty unlikely that I'll ever come back for brunch. If I do swing by for just drinks or dinner though, instead of their much tastier sister restaurant downstairs, I'll update accordingly.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Like Lolinda, there's an elevator inside that takes you up to the rooftop, which, while somewhat packed, does have tables that are accessible.

Bathroom - Didn't use them.
author: Johnny W.

description: Wonderful night out with the hubby!  Atmosphere was great and lively.  Staff was attentive and the food was delicious!  Nice hip place with views of the city.  I would definitely try this place again!
author: Nina E.

description: Only went for happy hour but loved the margarita and apps. I also particularly like the attention to detail on the rooftop; the plastic to block rain and wind is really well done. I plan on returning for dinner during warm weather.
author: L. W.

description:
I'm a little scared to write a review about my favorite brunch place in the Mission. But I must spread the knowledge to my lovely Yelp fam!! 

Reasons Why El Techo Is The Absolute Bomb Diggity: 

(1) Easy brunch reservations 
- reserve on Opentable! Spots are plentiful as long as you book a couple weeks early. I hate brunch lines and reservations are my sliced bread. 
(2) Look cool in front of your friends 
- waltz to the check-in counter, tell them your name, and usher your group up the elevator. Elevator opens onto rooftop deck. WOW!!! Your friends are wide-eyed in admiration of how knowledgeable and hip you are.  
(3) Unbelievable view of the skyline 
- one of the best brunch views you'll get in SF. Plus, it's outside, which makes you feel all the more connected with the city~~
(4) Yummy alcohol 
- get a pitcher of the margarita (La Paloma is about $10 cheaper and still very tasty) or the sangria! Yum. 
(5) Heat lamps on chilly days 
- very helpful for those random August Sundays when you thought it would be sunny and 80 but it's actually foggy and 60. 
(6) Gallivant around the Mission afterwards because it's the best neighborhood in town 
- Ritual for afternoon coffee! Bi Rite for afternoon ice cream! Valencia Street for afternoon window shopping! Dolores Park for afternoon lounging! The Mission is your oyster! 

What's good here: 
* Benedictos (two poached eggs, jalapeno cornbread, chorizo, spinach, chile hollandaise) = my favorite. You don't get a huge amount of food, but the jalapeno cornbread is to die for. 
* Chorizo scramble (roasted vegetables, chorizo, avocado, potatoes, chipotle, brioche) = quite a bit of food, if you tend to eat more. Delicious combination of flavors that doesn't leave you feeling like a blob of lard. 

Tip #1: Make sure you watch the elevator button after you press it. For some reason, the last 2 times I've gone the elevator comes down but then just sits there without opening (the button light turns off). Then when someone else comes and presses the button and it opens, you feel like a complete fool. DON'T BE A FOOL! WATCH THE BUTTON!! 

Tip #2: Want to take pictures of the fantastic view? Sure, take some in the main dining area, but there's an open area by the bathrooms (on the right side of the elevator if you're facing it) where you can take photos to your heart's desire without bothering other patrons of the restaurant.

Tip #3: It's pronounced El Techo. Like Te-cho with a ch. Not tecko. Yes, we're in the city of tech, but the origin of the name is from Spanish (el techo means roof).
author: Christine L.

description:
First off, there is a HUGE line when you arrive. If you're trying to eat you want to tell the host you want to eat and NOT go to the bar. If you want just the bar, you wait in line.

I put my name in to eat but I also waited in line to see what would be first. I ended up getting into the bar first. I ordered drinks and an appetizer at the bar side. Then, I got the text that my table was ready. My bar server told me he'd transfer over my order to my new table. It turns out my order never got transferred so we were waiting forever for nothing. 

Then we order our meal and waited atleast 50 mins and our food never came. I asked our server to check the status of our order and apparently it had never made it into the computer system. So again, we were waiting forever for nothing! 

When our food finally came it WAS delicious! I ordered 1 lbs of chicharrones de carne. Soooo juicy! 

I gave this restaurant 3 stars because although service was awful, the food was delicious! Great job chefs! We ended up getting a huge discount which was very nice of the manager!
author: Brittany S.

description:
Rooftop bars are my favorite, and there is such a lack of them in the Bay Area compared to southern California. So El Techo has been on my list forever and ever, but the rumors of insane crowds and the booked-out-for-weeks reservations on OpenTable scared me off a tad. 
We got extremely lucky and wandered up right before 3 p.m, when they turn over from brunch. We joined a growing line (seriously it felt like entering a nightclub, but the hipster sf version) and went up right away! Awkward gentrification guilt and moral panic aside, this spot is amazing. You can't beat the view of the city, and on a nice day you can see absolutely everything. 
We didn't eat anything, and split a pitcher of maragaritas. I was surprised at how reasonably priced drinks are here, I guess even the hottest spot in the Mission is more affordable than a mediocre bar in FiDi or Soma. The margaritas weren't the strongest but they were tasty. 
The service was great for us as well. Our waiter was really cool and suggested we go ahead and get a pitcher, since if either of us got a second drink it would be the same price. He delivered our drinks and disappeared until the literal second our bottle of water was empty. Replaced immediately, and away he goes again. I'm stunned at how smooth operations are here given how packed it is 24/7. 
Overall, this is a gem in the city. Knocking off a star because getting here is a pain, and if you aren't here at 2:40 you won't get in without a huge wait. I despise waiting for food because I suck, so it says a lot that I would love to come back here!
author: Delaynie K.

description:
The Good: 
The atmosphere is great, beautiful view, the food is pretty good. It's a nice spot for drinks and appetizers with friends. 

The Bad:
Customer service is not great. We had to ask them multiple times for plates, utensils,napkins etc. the portions of food are very small. The drinks are watered down.
author: Angelina A.

description: It seems hard to find lively places like this in San Francisco and was glad to find it during our weekend getaway. The atmosphere was exactly what we were looking for - great views, fun drinks, down to earth, not too crowded, but crowded enough, and of course, the chips and guac. Yum! It was a perfect first stop on our bar hopping night out & put us in the party spirit!
author: Eva B.

description:
As an avid Alamo Draft House patron my friend ranted and raved that I needed to try El Techo. 
I came in early for a little birthday gathering to secure a table and was excited to try out their menu options. Thankfully I arrived early and got a table because they reach max capacity around 6pm. 
While waiting for my friends to join I ordered La Paloma, chip & guac and the beef empanadas. 
The food arrived quickly and I made haste on the guac. Eventually I moved over to the empanadas. 

Unfortunately, there was an odd object in my empanada mixture. At first I thought it was bone while I was chewing and thought, yeah that can happen but upon further inspection the item was a twist of metal and looked similar to the twisted part of a wine cage for beer/sparking beverages. 
Naturally I stopped eating and after about 5 min of waiting for the waitress, I pointed out the object. She offered to take it off my bill and offered to replace the meal with the identical item. As a Chef the first thing I would do is remove that item from the menu. It would be 86'd for the evening. A hazardous item was in a mixture that is prepped out for many servings.
Offer something else would have been acceptable but not the same item. It's careless to offer the item again and potentially have others experience this hazard. What's a couple hundred of dollars in food cost vs someone else finding that item again. Them choking in it. I declined the offer. 
As I continued to sip on my drink I wondered if a Manager would arrive and apologize for the incident. Thank me for pointing it out and assure me that it was removed from the menu. Well that never happened. 

Perhaps 15 min later my waitress returned to say that something would be sent over and to not be surprised. I wondered again, why send something out before asking if I was allergic to anything? 

So far it's a no on the return to el techo. 
Other issues: 
Sat and 3 water glasses presented but no water. 
Finished my drink and was not asked if I wanted to order another.
Received an apology of sweet Fried Plantains. However it was to replace a savory item (Not a dessert fan) Why didn't anyone ask? 

In the service industry when something unfortunate happens to a guest you try your best to make the experience better. I moved on to another nearby restaurant.
author: Ari E.

description: We came on a rainy day and the rooftop bar was bumping! I had a delicious quesadilla with brisket in the middle and it hit the spot. The happy hour deals were really nice, and the margaritas and chips and salsa were great. I would love to come back.
author: Emily W.

description:
El Techo is a gem in the Mission District.

This is my SF friend's favourite spot in the city so I couldn't not try it.

We visited the venue on a Thursday evening, put our name in the queue and waited for the guy at the entrance to call us.

We waited approx. 15 to go upstairs and man, what a view! 

El Techo has an open terrace that overlooks the city and in clear sky day, the view is really jaw dropping. 

The food (traditional Mexican) was delicious and very filling and we happily washed it down with some margaritas.

The service was not intrusive but attentive.
Surprisingly, none m rushed us off to leave the table after we finished our food and we ended up staying there for almost 2.5 hours.

Prices are possibly higher than any other Mexican restaurant in SF but they are all worth it. We spent $40 (excl. tips) for 5 of the 'small' plates that we shared, one dessert each and a pinch of Margaritas.

Definitely a place worth visiting.

P.S. Bare in mind that if you are going for drinks only, the wait can be way longer than 15 mins, especially on weekends. Also, they do happy hour every day from 4PM-6PM.
author: Marta F.

description: Mark is AMAZING! I always go and try to sit in the section he works because he does an outstanding service, Not only did he rock but made us feel at home. I took my girl friends who are new to  town and he made it a great experience for all of us. He is so charming, knowledge of the menu, and made our visit exceptional. Thank you Mark...You rock!
author: Gardenia H.

description:
Rooftop bar what's up?

Ok, there's a line on the sidewalk but whatever. Take me to that rooftop with a gorgeous view of SF. This is my only rooftop experience here in the bay which is so foreign to me. Where all the rooftop pool parties and dance floors like LA?

Anyways, the sangria rocks my world. Go straight for the pitcher. I ordered a glass and ended up with four by the end of the night. It would've been a sick deal if I just went big to begin with.

The chips must be homemade because I'm crazy addicted. Try it with the guac or the ceviche and you'll feel the same vibes I do.

Get a spot under the heat lamp. You can never tell with the weather and it's better to get cozy than freeze.

Service is solid, too. The bar can sometimes get crazy busy so be patient. They didn't forget about you!
author: Nitar L.

description:
If there wasn't a couple cool bars to chill at to pass the 1 hour + wait time it took to get a table, I would say this place wasn't thaaaat worth it, but since there was... it made for a better overall experience. Arrived right around 8pm, hostess took our name and stated a 40 minute wait(ended up being over an hour). Got a couple drinks at the movie theatre bar to the left. Finally got seated at the top at a two top table and to our surprise it was heated on the rooftop "thank god!" Ordered another couple drinks, no meat empanadas, and the 1/2 pound carnitas. My meal was great, I normally don't eat pork, but was willing and did not regret my order. 

Service: I have experience as being a hostess & server and I thought all I had encounters with staff were great. After many complaints and rude customers asking the hostesses when their table would be ready or why they had to stand in line if they just wanted drinks, etc etc... they always answered in a friendly tone! 

My server (on receipt says 11057-Steph) gave excellent service! She was friendly, prompt, and was kind enough to split the bill exactly how we asked! 

Would recommend!
author: Hoku L.

description:
Very cute restaurant in the mission for brunch. 

I made reservations for 3 at 12:30PM on a Saturday.  Avoid the wait, make a reservation! The place is constantly busy, so just don't run the risk of having to wait.  There's a host right at the door of the restaurant that checks you in and makes sure your table is ready. If all is good to go then you walk over to the elevator and take it up to the rooftop restaurant.  There's a host to greet you by the elevator and shows you to your table. 

Service was pretty solid. Our waitress was nice, but hard to find sometimes. We had to grab her attention a few times for boxes and our check.

We started off with drinks, which I got the Michelada.  It was executed perfectly! I love Pacifico, so I was bound to like this michelada. They added the perfect amount of lime and chili. The rim was lined with a chili/salt mixture that was perfect to get a nice extra spicy kick from each sip. 

Now for the food:

Chicharrones de Carne (1/2 Pound $15): This was more than enough for the 3 of us. I had no idea the portion size would be that big. It seemed a lot more than 1/2 pound, but I'm not complaining! More leftovers for me! I've had all different takes on chicharonnes.  Whether it's all crispy skin or super crispy meat and skin.  This take was definitely more on the meaty side.  There was a good crisp to it, but still tender where you could pull the meat apart. It had a sweet and savory taste to it as if sugar was lightly sprinkled on top.  It was really delicious! They provide salsa, lime, and tortillas to go with it. They also provided escabech, which reminded me of Asian shrimp chips. 

Ceviche de Camaron ($13): So glad I ordered this and not a full brunch entrée after inhaling those chicharrones.  The ceviche was perfectly light and refreshing.  There were plenty of shrimp in there, so don't worry about them skimping you. 

Quesadilla de Pibil ($11): My sister ordered this and loved the taste of the pork.  It was marinated and braised to perfection. The tortilla they used wasn't too heavy and appeared to be homemade. If you're a fan of quesadillas then these definitely won't disappoint you.

Benedictos ($14): Holy jalapeno cornbread! They literally put a brick of cornbread on your plate.  To me it seemed like a bit too much cornbread, but my cousin seemed to enjoy it.  He eats a lot, so that may explain it. I tasted some of it and I will say that the cornbread was indeed delicious! If you're going to order this, just be make sure your stomach is well prepared. It's a heavy dish!

Overall, a great brunch spot! The rooftop was nice, but the view wasn't anything spectacular.  But, really? Can you expect to get a truly great view of the Mission? Also if you're not seated directly next to the edge of the building, you won't really see anything.  It's always nice to enjoy brunch outdoors though! And yes, the place is a tad bit pricey. But, I already looked at the menu and knew what I was getting myself into before I dined here. The food was great, so I felt like it was worth it.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Love love love this place, it's a Latin American rooftop bar and restaurant. Lots of small plates and things to choose from and great views of the city can be enjoyed. Service is also great. I like to take my girlfriend here on date night to celebrate or to just have a nice meal and chat. Don't be afraid of the entrance which is dark and shared with an apartment building, just trust that the doorman is legit and take the elevator up to the restaurant for a great meal! Also in a lively neighborhood so it's a good place to grab dinner and then walk around the shops afterwards on a Friday or Saturday night.
author: Myles L.

description: Seriously so good. If you want to get in without a reservation I would suggest getting there early to make sure you get a table. Luckily we were able to give the hostess a phone number and we had a table available just ten minutes after they open at 11am. The view was amazing, and the chorizo scramble was absolutely delicious. Definitely recommend if you're in the area.
author: Makenzie W.

description:
I'd marry this restaurant if I could. My friend brought me here after leaving a little early from outsidelands. I think we got there around 9-930. There was a ridiculous line for the bar, but if you go to the front and tell them you want to just eat at the restaurant they'll put your name down and the wait cuts down from an hour to half an hour probably. Haha no but really I think we waited half an hour to get in. 

But their food is soooooo worth the wait. The chicharones!!! It's life changing. Their tortillas are thicker than usual but also soft, and SO delicious. The meat's super tender and smoky flavor to it. Their chile sauces and even their pickled side of veggies (cauliflower, carrots, peppers) that come with it. Everything about the dish was just so well put together and so good. It's the first food I was craving as soon as I got back to LA. 

My friend says their drinks are also really good. Too bad I wasn't in the drinking mood that night. It's a half outdoorsy seating that allows you to see what they're cooking from your seat with dim Amber lighting at night. The only downfall is the wait for the place, but I suppose where do you not wait in SF especially if it's good.
author: Jane K.

description:
I love rooftop bars. Or really any bar with a nice view. I'd tried going to El Techo de Lolinda years ago, but it was a nice day and the wait was 1.5 hours. So I gave up and went to another destination. On Thursday, August 13th around 8pm, I decided to try again. We were a party of three and only waited about 15-20 mins in line. We got drinks and snacks.

Chuzos: three skewers ($19)
*Carne (+$1): flap meat, onion, zucchini, panca glaze
*Pollo: chicken, red onion, aji amarillo glaze
*Chorizo: hand-made chorizo, panca glaze
The skewers had a nice char. The chorizo had great flavor and the chicken was tender. The steak was a little overcooked for me and too chewy.

Drinks:
*Sangria: red wine, brandy, citrus, pineapple ($25 pitcher)
*La paloma: pueblo viejo tequila, grapefruit, agave, lime, soda ($10 single)
*Chilcano: huamani pisco, lime, passion fruit, ginger, bitters ($10)
*Tres amigos: ocho plata, victoria lager, house sangrita  ($10)

I thought all of their drinks were kind of weak. The sangria was very light. I wanted it to pack more of a punch. I also ordered the Chilcano thinking it'd be refreshing, but it was very sweet.
